awd_abstract_narration:
The Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 is the landmark civil rights legislation that prohibits discrimination and ensures equal opportunity and access for persons with disabilities. Although progress has been made, people with disabilities continue to be employed at rates much lower than the rest of the population. This lower employment rate is especially true of Americans who are deaf/hard of hearing (deaf/hh). Data from 2016 shows that approximately 54% of deaf/hh individuals age 25-64 participated in the labor force, compared to approximately 78% of hearing individuals. College graduation can provide major economic benefits for deaf/hh individuals who earn 2.6 times more than non-college graduates. Being employed in STEM provides an even greater benefit, since deaf/hh individuals in STEM occupations earn 34% more than their counterparts in non-STEM fields. The ATE Technological Education Center for Deaf and Hard-of-Hearing Students, DeafTEC, works to increase the access of deaf/hh individuals to career information, to a technical education, and to gainful employment. DeafTEC is housed at the National Technical Institute for the Deaf (NTID) within the Rochester Institute of Technology. DeafTEC will transition to an ATE Resource Center that will use and build upon the exemplary materials and network developed as the DeafTEC National Center.

The DeafTEC Resource Center will: (1) leverage partnerships to broaden professional development opportunities on-site and online for high school teachers, community college faculty, and employers to improve access to learning and technician employment for deaf/hh students; (2) expand, enhance, and broadly disseminate DeafTEC's innovative online resources and curricula related to technical education and technician careers for deaf/hh students, including military veteran students with hearing loss; and (3) collaborate with and provide mentoring for prospective PIs and current ATE projects and centers on creating inclusive environments for deaf/hh students, including military veteran students with hearing loss. DeafTEC will broaden participation in STEM technician careers for deaf/hh individuals by providing resources that they and their teachers, counselors, employers, and co-workers can used to support success both in the classroom and on the job. The value of DeafTEC Center's resources on universal design, developmental math, and writing across the STEM curriculum extend beyond the deaf/hh community, with potential benefit to all STEM students who need additional resources and support to succeed.  This project is funded by the NSF Advanced Technological Education program that focuses on the education of technicians for the advanced-technology fields that drive the nation's economy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
DeafTEC: Technological Education Center for Deaf and Hard-of-Hearing Students was initially funded as a National Center of Excellence in 2011 and renewed in 2015 under award numbers 1104229 and 1501756. The DeafTEC Resource Center has expanded upon the exemplary materials and network established by the DeafTEC National Center and has served as a resource for high schools and community colleges that educate DHH students in STEM-related programs and for employers hiring DHH individuals.

The DeafTEC Resource Center has broadened professional development opportunities through various initiatives, including:

MODE (Math Observations in Deaf Education) webinar series invites different guests for each webinar to discuss in ASL a particular current topic in math education. Webinars are presented in an informal talk show format, complete with visual aids and teaching ideas. Nine webinars were offered, attracting 2,100 registrants and 1,183 attendees.

Teaching Strategies for Deaf and Hard-of-Hearing Student Engagement in Mathematics an eight-session discussion of Peter Liljedahl's book, Building Thinking Classrooms in Mathematics, Grades K-12: Teaching Practices for Enhancing Learning, offered to 18 high school and middle school teachers of the deaf.

National DeafTEC and NRSC Math Conference offered at RIT/NTID from November 7-9, 2023, with 97 attendees.

Top Ten Tips for Teaching Student Veterans from the Classroom to Online webinars offered with 170 registrants and 108 attendees.

Partnership with the Association of Higher Education and Disability (AHEAD) on their 2023 Equity & Excellence: Access in Higher Education Conference  provided professional development for community college faculty and disability services personnel on fostering equitable higher education experiences for students with disabilities. This included:

  • Supporting 15 teams of two from community colleges to attend the conference, each team consisting of a STEM faculty member and a disability services staff member, with mandatory pre- and post-group meetings.

  • Adding a DeafTEC concurrent session track to the conference schedule, addressing service provision and best practices for working with D/HH students and student veterans with hearing loss in STEM programs, totaling 9 sessions and 14.5 hours.

  • Establishing a community of practice with the DeafTEC supported conference participants.

The Resource Center has expanded, enhanced, and disseminated various DeafTEC's innovative online resources, including:

Self-Paced Online Learning  

  • For Employers: The Working Together: Deaf & Hearing People online launched in 2017 and redesigned in 2020 is a five-module course designed to help employers create an inclusive workplace environment for both deaf and hearing workers that encourages effective communication and helps all employees realize their full potential. To date 1,0278 register for the course and 363 completed all five modules

  • For Educators: Project Access Online launched July 2022 is a four-module course that explores ways to optimize teaching in the classroom, provides real-life strategies, and provides extensive online resources to help teachers and faculty modify their teaching behaviors to provide greater access to learning for deaf students, which benefits all students. To date, 106 registered for this course and 61 completed all four modules.

Tips and Tale Website Section is a collection of lessons learned and best practices based on our experience in offering DeafTEC professional development and student STEM activities. It includes "tales" about what worked and what didn't, suggestions for student STEM activities, and professional development offerings. It also provides logistical information in the form of checklists and do's and don'ts for timelines, budgets, organization, and access services.

Khan Academy ASL Demonstration Website. As the Khan Academy Language Advocate for ASL, DeafTEC recreated all 197 videos, totaling 17 hours of instruction, for Khan's Algebra Basics course in ASL. This course is now available in ASL on the Khan Academy website and is currently being piloted in schools for the deaf.

The Resource Center has been effectively reaching educators, employers, and students through broad dissemination across multiple channels. Since 2021, DeafTEC has launched several social media platforms, including Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram. Regular posts on these platforms allowed DeafTEC to engage a diverse range of stakeholders in its role as a Resource Center.

Industry partnerships play a crucial role in expanding DeafTEC's impact. For instance, DeafTEC partnered with CompTIA to offer two virtual career panels for high school students featuring deaf professionals. The first panel, "Virtual Career Panel of Cybersecurity Experts," included a deaf cybersecurity professional and reached over 6,000 viewers. The second webinar, "Information Technology is for Everyone," featured an all-deaf panel and moderator, and was viewed by1,682 students across 142 schools.

The Resource Center has also actively collaborated with the ATE community through its participation in the PI Conference and HI-TEC, advisory roles in other ATE projects, and the AccessATE project. In partnership with AccessATE, DeafTEC developed a new series of nine tip sheets, A.C.E. It!, designed to help faculty "ACE" conversations with potential employers by Advocating for their students, informing employers on effective Communication with employees with disabilities, and Educating employers on best practices.
